channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Morocco Said to Ban Sale of Burqas, Citing Security Concerns
item.media:description: A market in Tetuan, Morocco. Relatively few Moroccan women wear the burqa, a full-body veil generally seen in more conservative Muslim societies.
item.media:credit: Raquel Maria Carbonell Pagola/LightRocket, via Getty Images
item.description: Although the government did not confirm the ban, media reports said vendors and merchants received notice of the prohibition on the full-body veil.
item.dc:creator: AIDA ALAMI

item.title: Scientists Map Vast Peat Swamps, a Storehouse of Carbon, in Central Africa
item.media:description: Under the Cuvette Centrale wetlands in Central Africa, scientists found a storehouse of carbon as large as New York State.
item.description: The peatlands, covering an area the size of New York State, contain billions of tons of stored carbon but are vulnerable to warming and development.
item.dc:creator: HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: Young Symbol of Afghan Resilience Joins List of Lost Leaders
item.media:description: Abdul Ali Shamsi, right, arriving in Farah province to visit victims of a Taliban massacre in 2013.
item.description: Abdul Ali Shamsi, the Kandahar deputy governor, was among 11 killed in a bombing seemingly tailored to shake the faith in government he had sought to restore.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and TAIMOOR SHAH

item.title: Banda Aceh Journal: As Shariah Experiment Becomes a Model, Indonesia’s Secular Face Slips
item.media:description: Religious officers led a youth onstage before a public whipping in Banda Aceh, Indonesia, in August. The youth was punished for dating outside marriage, which is against Shariah, or Islamic law.
item.description: In recent years, the Muslim-majority nation has drifted in a conservative direction, and a province dominated by the legal code of Islam is no longer an outlier.
item.dc:creator: JON EMONT

item.title: Rex Tillerson’s South China Sea Remarks Foreshadow Possible Foreign Policy Crisis
item.media:description: Rex W. Tillerson, the nominee for secretary of state, told senators on Wednesday that China’s actions in the South China Sea were “akin to Russia’s taking of Crimea.”
item.description: In nomination hearings, Mr. Tillerson called for China to be denied access to its artificial islands, which would be a remarkable change in the U.S. approach to the disputed waters.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: South Korea’s Blacklist of Artists Adds to Outrage Over Presidential Scandal
item.media:description: The South Korean artist Hong Sung-dam in 2014 with his painting depicting President Park Geun-hye as a scarecrow. Mr. Hong is one of thousands of artists reportedly blacklisted by Ms. Park’s government.
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.description: A blacklist by President Park Geun-hye’s government affected more than 9,000 artists, reports say, leading to introspection about the country’s authoritarian past.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Christopher Steele, Ex-Spy Who Compiled Trump Dossier, Goes to Ground
item.media:description: Journalists on Thursday outside the London offices of Orbis Business Intelligence Ltd., co-founded by the former MI6 agent Christopher Steele.
item.description: The former MI6 agent was said to have hurriedly left his home in southern England when he knew his identity was to be revealed.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Brother and Sister Charged With Hacking Prominent Italians
item.media:description: An Italian police investigation called Eye Pyramid led to the arrest of a brother and sister on charges of hacking into thousands of phones and computers.
item.media:credit: Italian State Police, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: The police described the case as a vast cyberattack on institutions and individuals, including government officials and Freemasons.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI and ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Spain Dismisses Terror and Hate Crime Case Against Puppeteers
item.media:description: A demonstrator protesting the detention of the two puppeteers, Raúl García Pérez and Alfonso Lázaro de la Fuente, in Madrid last year.
item.description: The judge found insufficient evidence in the case, seen as a bellwether for whether Europe’s antiterrorism fight threatened free speech and protest rights.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Fewer Migrants Entered Germany in 2016, and Rejections Increased
item.media:description: Afghans who were deported from Germany left Kabul International Airport in Afghanistan in December.
item.description: About 280,000 new asylum seekers arrived in 2016, down from the 890,000 migrants in 2015, the interior minister said, as the rate of rejected asylum seekers went up.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: What in the World: Talking to In-laws Can Be Hard. In Some Languages, It’s Impossible.
item.description: A geographically widespread practice known as avoidance speech imposes strict rules on how one speaks — or doesn’t — to the parents of a spouse.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Kunduz Attack in November Killed 33 Civilians, U.S. Military Says
item.media:description: Villagers gathering around some of those who were killed during heavy fighting in Boz Qandahari, in Kunduz Province, in November.
item.description: An investigation found that the firefight and airstrikes injured 27 others, American military officials said.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Old Espionage Ruse, With a Modern Twist: Israelis Say Hamas Used Online Seduction
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers in an exercise with laser-equipped rifles and an interactive screen at the Camp Tsur training base in southern Israel last year.
item.description: Operatives used flirtatious messages on social networks to persuade Israeli soldiers to download apps that turned their cellphones into tools for spying, military officials say.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: ‘We’ll Grow Again’: Bangladesh Cafe Attacked by Terrorists Reopens
item.media:description: Employees waited for customers on Wednesday at the newly reopened Holey Artisan Bakery in Dhaka, Bangladesh.
item.description: “What else is there to do except move on?” said one of the owners of the Holey Artisan Bakery, which was attacked by gunmen in July.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and MAHER SATTAR

item.title: Taliban Release Video of Foreign Professors Abducted in Kabul
item.description: The 13-minute video is the insurgents’ first confirmation that they were behind the abduction of American and Australian professors in August.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Wintry Blast in Greece Imperils Refugees in Crowded Camps
item.media:description: Laundry belonging to Syrian refugees was covered with snow on Tuesday at the Ritsona refugee camp in Greece.
item.description: Snow, freezing rain and flooding threatened tens of thousands of people, many of them living in tents and other flimsy shelters without heat.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
United Nations High Commission for Refugees

item.title: Nepal Removes Leader of Post-Quake Rebuilding Effort
item.media:description: Bidhya Laxmi Prajapati cleared debris last year from the site of her house in Kathmandu, Nepal. Her home was destroyed in one of two earthquakes in 2015.
item.description: A cabinet decision to replace the official with his predecessor is likely to further delay reconstruction nearly two years after two earthquakes struck the country.
item.dc:creator: RAJNEESH BHANDARI and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Malta Takes the Reins of a Frayed and Anxious European Union
item.media:description: Donald Tusk, the president of the European Council, right, and Prime Minister Joseph Muscat of Malta, left, during a meeting on Wednesday in Valletta, Malta.
item.description: The tiny country assumed the six-month rotating presidency of a 28-nation bloc that is facing enormous strain.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: Istanbul Journal: Snow Acts as a Magical Balm in an Anxious Turkey
item.media:description: The Sultanahmet Mosque, also known as the Blue Mosque, during snowfall in Istanbul on Sunday.
item.description: A blizzard, the heaviest snowfall since 2009, was just what the city needed as it struggles with anxiety amid terrorism and political instability.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Norway Becomes First Country to Start Switching Off FM Radio
item.media:description: The Norwegian radio host Geir Schau, right, and a well-known radio listener in the country, Berith Olderskog, left, joined to symbolically shut down the northern part of Norway’s FM radio network in favor of digital radio at a ceremony on Wednesday in Bodo.
item.description: The country began turning off FM broadcasting on Wednesday, a move to digital that has some people worried about the consequences.
item.dc:creator: HENRIK PRYSER LIBELL

item.title: Iceland Forms Coalition Government After Months of Talks
item.media:description: The new Icelandic government in Reykjavik, the capital, on Wednesday.
item.description: The agreement no doubt came as a relief to many in the island nation, but the lineup of the new administration dashed hopes of radical change.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: China, Fanning Patriotism, Adds 6 Years to War with Japan in History Books
item.media:description: Visitors to a museum in Beijing that commemorates the conflict known outside China as the Second Sino-Japanese War.
item.description: The “Eight-Year War of Resistance Against Japanese Aggression” will now be the “14-Year War,” with the starting date moved back to 1931, the government said.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Obituary: Vo Quy, Father of Environmental Conservation in Vietnam, Dies at 87
item.media:description: Vo Quy, center, and workers at the Vu Quang nature reserve in central Vietnam examined plant specimens in 1996.
item.description: Dr. Quy helped create Vietnam’s first national park in the 1960s and served as an intermediary as the country and the United States moved to address the effects of Agent Orange.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Russia’s Sexual Blackmail Didn’t Die With the Soviets
item.media:description: President-elect Donald J. Trump at a rally in Michigan in December. “The Kremlin has no compromising dossier on Mr. Trump,” a spokesman said on Wednesday.
item.description: Whatever did or did not happen in Donald J. Trump’s Moscow hotel suite in 2013, Russia has a long record of collecting compromising material on those it perceives as enemies.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS and ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Samsung Group Leader Is Named a Suspect in South Korean Bribery Inquiry
item.media:description: Jay Y. Lee, the vice chairman of Samsung, at the National Assembly in Seoul, South Korea, last month. The special prosecutor’s office recommended that he be investigated on suspicion of perjury.
item.description: Jay Y. Lee was summoned for questioning in connection with the corruption scandal that led to President Park Geun-hye’s impeachment.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Caroline Kennedy, an Ambassador Whose Role Transcended the Embassy
item.media:description: Caroline Kennedy, the ambassador to Japan, at her office in the United States Embassy in Tokyo this month. In her three years in Japan she sought to convey to women across the country a quiet message of empowerment.
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.description: She helped manage relations with Japan, a vital ally, and, as the first female ambassador there, was consequential for a traditionally male-dominated nation.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Taiwan Responds After China Sends Carrier to Taiwan Strait
item.media:description: China’s lone aircraft carrier, the Liaoning, with accompanying ships during a drill in the South China Sea in December.
item.description: Rising tensions between the two nations present a foreign policy challenge for the incoming administration of Donald J. Trump.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The U.S. Must Talk to North Korea
item.media:description: The portraits of late North Korean leaders Kim Il-sung and Kim Jong-il in Pyongyang.
item.description: Bilateral diplomacy is the best way for the Trump administration to limit the growing nuclear threat.
item.dc:creator: SIEGFRIED S. HECKER

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Does Israel Really Have a Corruption Problem?
item.media:description: A bodyguard closing the gates to the official residence of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Jan. 2, blocking the view as the press awaited the arrival of police investigators looking into gifts Mr. Netanyahu received.
item.description: The prime minister is (once again) investigated for graft. Israelis shrug.
item.dc:creator: SHMUEL ROSNER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Old Labour, New Labour, No Labour
item.description: Social democracy is dying in Britain.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW J. GOODWIN

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER
